thread.title: Benjamin Netanyahu seeks closer ties with Britain in face of Iran’s 'aggression’
thread.title_full: Benjamin Netanyahu seeks closer ties with Britain in face of Iran’s 'aggression’

author: Sophie Jamieson
title: Benjamin Netanyahu seeks closer ties with Britain in face of Iran’s 'aggression’
text:
I sraeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has said he will seek to “tighten” relations with the UK in the face of “extraordinary aggression” from Iran ahead of a meeting with Theresa May on Monday.
Speaking before flying to Britain Mr Netanyahu, who is also preparing to visit Donald Trump’s new administration in Washington DC , said: "We are in a period of diplomatic opportunities and challenges.
"The opportunities stem from the fact that there is a new administration in Washington, and a new government in Britain.
"I intend to speak with both of them about tightening relations, between each side and Israel and trilaterally."
New admin in US, new gov in Britain, new diplomatic opportunities for Israel. I have meetings in London tomorrow & in Washington next week.
— Benjamin Netanyahu (@netanyahu) February 5, 2017 M r Netanyahu said the first issue he would want to discuss with Mrs May and Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson would be Iran.
"They are trying to test the boundaries with extraordinary aggression, gall and defiance. "I think that the most important thing at the moment is that countries like the US, which will take the lead, Israel and the UK line up together against Iran's aggression and set clear limits to it.”
Downing Street has said talks in No 10 would focus on bilateral relations between the UK and Israel including the potential for more trade post-Brexit.
A spokesman said while Mrs May was expected to raise concerns about Israeli settlement building, it would only form a small part of their discussions.
ממשל חדש בוושינגטון, ממשלה חדשה בבריטניה - הזדמנויות מדיניות לישראל. אפעל מול שניהם להידוק היחסים בינינו, מחר בלונדון ובשבוע הבא בוושינגטון pic.twitter.com/KwTBYkVqaX 
— Benjamin Netanyahu (@netanyahu) February 5, 2017 M r Netanyahu has pressed ahead with a number of construction projects to build new homes in West Bank settlements in the wake of Mr Trump’s inauguration.
His announcement last week of 3,000 new homes followed plans just days earlier for an additional 2,500 homes in the West Bank and more than 550 homes in east Jerusalem.
The Palestinians' claim to both areas, captured by Israel in the 1967 Mideast war, as parts of a future independent state, is a position that has wide international backing.
Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn has said the plans for new homes were illegal under international law and further undermined the prospect of a two-state solution to the conflict.
He said that it was "simply not good enough" for Mrs May to say that Israeli settlement building on occupied Palestinian land undermined trust in the Middle East peace process.
